challenge.instructions:
Understand Blazor rendering modes!

1. Create examples showing when to use each mode:

   STATIC SSR:
   - Product catalog page
   - Blog posts
   - Why: Fast, SEO, no interactivity needed

   INTERACTIVE SERVER:
   - Admin dashboard
   - Form with validation
   - Why: Complex logic on server, small payload

   INTERACTIVE WEBASSEMBLY:
   - Image editor
   - Game
   - Why: Works offline, no server calls

   INTERACTIVE AUTO:
   - E-commerce site
   - Social media feed
   - Why: Fast start, then offline capability

2. Print comparison table
3. Show .NET 8 configuration code
4. Explain trade-offs
challenge.hint: Static = no interactivity. Server = C# on server. WASM = C# in browser. Auto = starts Server, becomes WASM. Choose based on: speed, interactivity, offline needs.
commonStickingPoints: Using wrong mode: Static SSR for interactive app = no @onclick works! Must use Interactive* modes for interactivity. Static is like traditional HTML.
WASM download size: WebAssembly downloads .NET runtime + your app (5-10MB!). First load is slow. Use Auto mode to start fast, switch to WASM later.
Server scalability: InteractiveServer creates SignalR connection per user. 10,000 users = 10,000 connections! WASM scales better (runs in browser).
Mixing modes: Can use different modes for different components! Product list (Static), shopping cart (Server), image editor (WASM). Mix and match!
